Situation1: They oversee multiple teams, resolving conflicts and delays to ensure a critical project meets a strict deadline.
Expectation2: Observe kosher dietary laws in daily meals
Situation2: The pantry is stocked with kosher ingredients, and alternative snacks are readily available.
Story:
I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, the clock ticking down to our project’s final deadline. My phone buzzed with messages from team leads—another delay, a miscommunication, a supplier issue. As the architect, everyone looked to me to keep things moving, to resolve every hiccup and keep the project on track. I barely had time to breathe, let alone eat. 

My stomach growled, reminding me I hadn’t eaten since early morning. I glanced at the break room, where the team had ordered takeout to keep everyone fueled. The smell of pizza and sandwiches drifted down the hall. I knew the pantry was stocked with kosher snacks, but they felt so meager compared to the hot food everyone else was enjoying. My colleagues urged me to grab a slice, just this once, to keep my energy up and stay with the team. 

I felt the weight of their expectations pressing in—be present, be efficient, don’t slow down. But my own expectations tugged at me too: honor my faith, keep kosher, even when it’s inconvenient. I stood there, torn, the demands of my roles pulling me in opposite directions.
